## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

```typescript
      Effect.provide(MockMessageRepository),
      Effect.provide(MockNotificationService),
      Effect.tap((messageId) =>
        Effect.sync(() => {
          expect(messageId).toEqual(expectedMessageId)
        })
      ),
      Effect.asVoid
    )
  )
})
```

(file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)

(file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

Exit code: 0
Wall time: 0 seconds
Output:
# dist-deps-prune

CLI utility that scans a built `dist/` directory to find **actually used** external packages, reports unused dependencies, and can prune `package.json` for release.

## Install

```bash
npm i -D @prover-coder-ai/dist-deps-prune
```

## Usage

### Scan only

```bash
npx @prover-coder-ai/dist-deps-prune scan --dist ./dist --package ./package.json
```

### Apply pruning

```bash
npx @prover-coder-ai/dist-deps-prune apply --dist ./dist --package ./package.json --write --prune-dev true
```

### Release mode (backup + restore)

```bash
npx @prover-coder-ai/dist-deps-prune release --dist ./dist --package ./package.json --command "npm publish"
```

### Restore package.json

```bash
npx @prover-coder-ai/dist-deps-prune restore --package ./package.json
```

## CI/CD (Release workflow)

Use the tool during release so only the `dist/`-used dependencies stay in the published package.
Below is a minimal GitHub Actions snippet that builds, prunes, publishes, and restores automatically:

```yaml
- name: Build dist
  run: pnpm build

- name: Publish with dist-deps-prune (auto restore)
  run: |
    npx @prover-coder-ai/dist-deps-prune release \
      --dist ./dist \
      --package ./package.json \
      --prune-dev true \
      --command "npm publish" \
      --silent
  env:
    NPM_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.NPM_TOKEN }}
```

If you already run a publish command (e.g., `changeset-publish`), just put it into `--command`.

## Notes

- Supports ESM + CJS static imports in `.js/.mjs/.cjs/.d.ts`.
- Handles scoped packages and subpaths (`@scope/pkg/path` ‚Üí `@scope/pkg`).
- Optional allowlist via `.dist-deps-prune.json`.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`
- Dependency injection —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ Layer pattern
- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:

```typescript
// CHANGE: <–∫—Ä–∞—Ç–∫–æ–µ –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∏–∑–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è>
// WHY: <–º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–µ/–∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω–æ–µ –æ–±–æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ>
// QUOTE(–¢–ó): "<–¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–∞—è —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–∞ —Ç—Ä–µ–±–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è>" | n/a
// REF: <REQ-ID –∏–∑ RTM –∏–ª–∏ –Ω–æ–º–µ—Ä —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏—è>
// SOURCE: <—Å—Å—ã–ª–∫–∞ —Å –¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–æ–π —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–æ–π –∏–∑ –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–µ–≥–æ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞> | n/a
// FORMAT THEOREM: <‚àÄx ‚àà Domain: P(x) ‚Üí Q(f(x))>
// PURITY: CORE | SHELL - —è–≤–Ω–∞—è –º–∞—Ä–∫–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∫–∞ —Å–ª–æ—è
// EFFECT: Effect<Success, Error, Requirements> - –¥–ª—è shell —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π
// INVARIANT: <–º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–π –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏>
// COMPLEXITY: O(time)/O(space) - –≤—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è –∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å
```

3. **–°–¢–†–û–ì–ê–Ø –î–û–ö–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–¶–ò–Ø –¢–ò–ü–û–í**:

```typescript
/**
 * –û—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ –≤ —á–∞—Ç —Å –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∫–æ–π
 *
 * @param message - –í–∞–ª–∏–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–µ —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º–æ–µ)
 * @param recipients - –ü–æ–ª—É—á–∞—Ç–µ–ª–∏ (non-empty array)
 * @returns Effect —Å MessageId –∏–ª–∏ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π –æ—à–∏–±–∫–æ–π
 *
 * @pure false - —Å–æ–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∏—Ç —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã –æ—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–∫–∏
 * @effect DatabaseService, NotificationService
 * @invariant ‚àÄm ‚àà Messages: sent(m) ‚Üí ‚àÉid: persisted(m, id)
 * @precondition message.content.length > 0 ‚àß recipients.length > 0
 * @postcondition ‚àÄr ‚àà recipients: notified(r, message) ‚à® error_logged(r)
 * @complexity O(n) where n = |recipients|
 * @throws Never - –≤—Å–µ –æ—à–∏–±–∫–∏ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ Effect
 */
```

4. **–ò–°–ß–ï–†–ü–´–í–ê–Æ–©–ò–ô –ü–ê–¢–¢–ï–†–ù-–ú–ê–¢–ß–ò–ù–ì**:

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

5. **–≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢–ù–ê–Ø –ê–†–•–ò–¢–ï–ö–¢–£–†–ê**:

```typescript
// CORE: –ß–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
interface MessageRepository {

  ) => Effect.Effect<Option<Message>, DatabaseError>
}

// SHELL: –ö–æ–Ω–∫—Ä–µ—Ç–Ω–∞—è —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏—è
const PostgresMessageRepository = Layer.effect(
  MessageRepositoryTag,

```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`

- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)

```typescript
}
```

```typescript
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(

  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Designing dist path resolution**

I'm defining new interfaces and functions to infer the distribution directory from package.json or CLI input, with logic to distinguish explicit CLI paths from inferred ones, and planning to handle path joining accordingly in the program.

**Refining dist inference and integration plan**

I'm settling on a simple approach with a pure core function inferring the dist directory from package.json and program logic joining it to package path when CLI dist isn't explicit, ensuring clean path normalization and safe relative handling. I'll reorder analyzeProject to read package.json earlier for dist resolution and plan CLI updates to track explicitness, adjusting config resolution accordingly. Testing will validate inference across common package.json patterns.

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Designing dist path resolution approach**

I'm planning to update the CLI args type to include a new field for explicit dist paths but won't change the config interface itself. I'll add a core function to resolve the dist path based on CLI input and package info, keeping pure logic there, while using shell utilities for path joins in the program layer. Tests for CLI won't need changes since no existing ones cover the new flag yet.

**Finalizing dist path resolution design**

I'm defining a new shell-level `resolveDistPath` function that calls a pure core inference function using package JSON and CLI inputs while leveraging the Path service for joins. To infer dist directories, I'm implementing detailed logic analyzing package entrypoints, exports, and files fields with helper functions to normalize and extract top-level paths. This approach balances architectural separation, handles CLI explicit flags, and supports correct scanning roots by inferring dist from package metadata when not explicitly set.

**Implementing dist path inference tests and integration**

I'm adding tests to validate dist directory inference from various package.json scenarios and integrating the core inference function into the program layer by resolving dist paths using the Path service with awareness of CLI explicit flags. This keeps inference logic pure and centralized while letting the program layer handle path joining and effect dependencies.

**Finalizing dist path resolution design**

I'm defining a new shell-level `resolveDistPath` function that calls a pure core inference function using package JSON and CLI inputs while leveraging the Path service for joins. To infer dist directories, I'm implementing detailed logic analyzing package entrypoints, exports, and files fields with helper functions to normalize and extract top-level paths. **Implementing dist path inference tests and integration**

This keeps inference logic pure and centralized while letting the program layer handle path joining and effect dependencies.

```typescript
    pipe(
      sendMessageUseCase(validCommand),
      Effect.provide(MockMessageRepository),
      Effect.provide(MockNotificationService),
      Effect.tap((messageId) =>
        Effect.sync(() => {
          expect(messageId).toEqual(expectedMessageId)
        })
      ),
      Effect.asVoid
    )
  )
})
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

3. **–°–¢–†–û–ì–ê–Ø –î–û–ö–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–¶–ò–Ø –¢–ò–ü–û–í**:

```typescript
/**
 * –û—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ –≤ —á–∞—Ç —Å –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∫–æ–π
```

4. **–ò–°–ß–ï–†–ü–´–í–ê–Æ–©–ò–ô –ü–ê–¢–¢–ï–†–ù-–ú–ê–¢–ß–ò–ù–ì**:

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

5. **–≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢–ù–ê–Ø –ê–†–•–ò–¢–ï–ö–¢–£–†–ê**:

```typescript
// CORE: –ß–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
interface MessageRepository {
  readonly save: (msg: Message) => Effect.Effect<MessageId, DatabaseError>

    id: MessageId

// SHELL: –ö–æ–Ω–∫—Ä–µ—Ç–Ω–∞—è —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏—è
const PostgresMessageRepository = Layer.effect(
  MessageRepositoryTag,
  Effect.gen(function* (_) {
    const db = yield* _(DatabaseService)
    return {
      save: (msg) => db.insert("messages", msg),
      findById: (id) => db.findOne("messages", { id })
    }
  })
)
```

6. **PROOF-–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–°–¢–í–ê –í PR**:


### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.

- Coordination and sequencing:

- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

 import { buildPrunePlan } from "../core/prune.js"
 import { buildReport, renderHumanReport, renderJsonReport } from "../core/report.js"
 import type { Report } from "../core/types.js"

@@
 interface AnalyzeResult {
   readonly report: Report
   readonly plan: PrunePlan
 }
+
+// CHANGE: resolve dist path from package.json when --dist is not provided
+// WHY: support non-standard build output directories without extra CLI flags
+// QUOTE(TZ): "–∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–ª –≥–¥–µ —Å–º–æ—Ç—Ä–µ—Ç—å –∑–∞–ø–∞–∫–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—É—é –≤–µ—Ä—Å–∏—é –∏—Å—Ö–æ–¥—è –∏–∑ package.json"
+// REF: req-dist-infer-2
+// SOURCE: n/a
+// FORMAT THEOREM: ‚àÄcli,pkg: dist(cli,pkg)=cli.dist if explicit else join(dirname(pkg), infer(pkg) ?? cli.dist)
+// PURITY: SHELL
+// EFFECT: n/a
+// INVARIANT: resolved distPath is deterministic for fixed inputs
+// COMPLEXITY: O(1)
+const resolveDistPath = (
+  cli: CliArgs,
+  pkg: Readonly<Record<string, unknown>>,
+  path: PathService
+): string => {
+  if (cli.distExplicit) {
+    return cli.dist
+  }
+  const inferred = inferDistDirFromPackageJson(pkg)
+  if (inferred === undefined) {
+    return cli.dist
+  }
+  return path.join(path.dirname(cli.packagePath), inferred)
+}
@@

-    const resolved = resolveConfig(cli, configFile)

+    const distPath = resolveDistPath(cli, pkg, path)

     const builtins = yield* _(loadBuiltinModules)
     const scan = yield* _(
       scanDist({
-        distPath: cli.dist,
+        distPath,
         patterns: resolved.patterns,
         ignorePatterns: resolved.ignorePatterns,
         strict: cli.strict,
         builtins
       })
     )
-    const pkg = yield* _(readPackageJson(cli.packagePath))
     const usedInDev = listDevDependenciesUsedInDist(scan.used, pkg)

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è

- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏

–ü–†–ò–ù–¶–ò–ü: –°–Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–∞ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª–∏–∑—É–µ–º, –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä—É–µ–º.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Reviewing path resolution logic**

I verified that the inferred distribution directory joins correctly with the package.json directory, producing expected relative paths like "dist" or "packages/foo/dist"; this should preserve existing behavior and work with default patterns referencing that path.

**Planning detailed tests for dist path inference**

I'm outlining four tests for `inferDistDirFromPackageJson` covering main, exports with JS prioritization, files fallback, and ignoring non-directory files, to ensure robust dist directory detection in various package.json scenarios.

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

```markdown
## –ú–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏–∏
```

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):

  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.

- Coordination and sequencing:

- Context hygiene:

- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`
- Dependency injection —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ Layer pattern
- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

6. **PROOF-–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–°–¢–í–ê –í PR**:

```markdown
## –ú–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏–∏

### –ò–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç—ã:

### –ü–æ—Å—Ç—É—Å–ª–æ–≤–∏—è:

### –í–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–Ω–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–¥–ª—è —Ä–µ–∫—É—Ä—Å–∏–∏):

- `processQueue: |queue| ‚Üí |queue| - 1` (—É–±—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç –Ω–∞ –∫–∞–∂–¥–æ–π –∏—Ç–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏)
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

–ê–†–•–ò–¢–ï–ö–¢–£–†–ù–´–ï –ü–†–ò–ù–¶–ò–ü–´:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`
- Dependency injection —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ Layer pattern
- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:

```typescript

// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(

  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),

)
```
