## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏

–ü–†–ò–ù–¶–ò–ü: –°–Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–∞ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª–∏–∑—É–µ–º, –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä—É–µ–º.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

**Confirming documentation sufficiency**

Tests passed and new functions include some TSDoc and comment blocks meeting guidelines, so additional README updates or fuller type invariants are optional but not mandatory. Next, I'll finalize the update plan.

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

```markdown
## –ú–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏–∏
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Summarizing final changes and tests**

The tool now infers the dist directory from `package.json` fields if `--dist` is not provided, joining the inferred path with the package directory‚Äîfor example, using `lib` from `packages/eslint-template/package.json` results in `packages/eslint-template/lib`. Tests were added verifying this behavior and run via `pnpm test`, which runs `lint:tests` and `vitest run`. Note that one integration test (`component-tagger.integration.test.ts`) is currently skipped. There were some warnings about npm config but no failures. Next steps could include updating the README or preparing a release. The summary is provided in Russian per the conversation language.

–°–¥–µ–ª–∞–ª –∞–≤—Ç–æ‚Äë–æ–ø—Ä–µ–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ dist‚Äë–ø—É—Ç–∏ –∏–∑ `package.json` (–µ—Å–ª–∏ `--dist` –Ω–µ –∑–∞–¥–∞–Ω), –ø–ª—é—Å —Ç–µ—Å—Ç—ã –Ω–∞ –ª–æ–≥–∏–∫—É –≤—ã–±–æ—Ä–∞ –ø–∞–ø–∫–∏.

- –ê–≤—Ç–æ‚Äë–∏–Ω—Ñ–µ—Ä–µ–Ω—Å dist –∏–∑ `main/module/exports/bin/files` –∏ –≤—ã–±–æ—Ä top‚Äëlevel –¥–∏—Ä–µ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä–∏–∏ (JS‚Äëentrypoints –≤ –ø—Ä–∏–æ—Ä–∏—Ç–µ—Ç–µ). –§–∞–π–ª: `packages/app/src/core/dist-path.ts`
- –ü–æ–¥–∫–ª—é—á–∏–ª –∏–Ω—Ñ–µ—Ä–µ–Ω—Å –≤ –æ—Ä–∫–µ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞—Ü–∏—é CLI: –µ—Å–ª–∏ `--dist` –Ω–µ –∑–∞–¥–∞–Ω, –±–µ—Ä—ë—Ç—Å—è –ø—É—Ç—å –æ—Ç–Ω–æ—Å–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ `dirname(package.json)` –∏ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑—É–µ—Ç—Å—è –¥–ª—è scan/config. –§–∞–π–ª: `packages/app/src/app/program.ts`
- –î–æ–±–∞–≤–∏–ª —Ñ–ª–∞–≥ `distExplicit` –≤ CLI args –¥–ª—è —Å–æ—Ö—Ä–∞–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è —è–≤–Ω–æ–≥–æ `--dist`. –§–∞–π–ª: `packages/app/src/core/cli.ts`
- –¢–µ—Å—Ç—ã –Ω–∞ –∏–Ω—Ñ–µ—Ä–µ–Ω—Å dist‚Äë–¥–∏—Ä–µ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä–∏–∏. –§–∞–π–ª: `packages/app/tests/core/dist-path.test.ts`

–ü—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä–∫–∏:
- `pnpm test` (lint:tests + vitest). –û–¥–∏–Ω —Ç–µ—Å—Ç–æ–≤—ã–π —Ñ–∞–π–ª –ø–æ–º–µ—á–µ–Ω –∫–∞–∫ skipped: `tests/app/component-tagger.integration.test.ts` ‚Äî —ç—Ç–æ –±—ã–ª–æ –∏ —Ä–∞–Ω—å—à–µ.

–°–ª–µ–¥—É—é—â–∏–µ —à–∞–≥–∏ (–ø–æ –∂–µ–ª–∞–Ω–∏—é):
1) –û–±–Ω–æ–≤–∏—Ç—å README —Å –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ–º –∞–≤—Ç–æ‚Äë–∏–Ω—Ñ–µ—Ä–µ–Ω—Å–∞ dist (–µ—Å–ª–∏ —Ö–æ—Ç–∏—Ç–µ, —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞—é).
2) –ü–æ–¥–ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç—å CI/Action, —á—Ç–æ–±—ã `--dist` –±—ã–ª –æ–ø—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª–µ–Ω –∏ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–µ—Ö–∞—Ç—å –Ω–∞ –∞–≤—Ç–æ‚Äë–∏–Ω—Ñ–µ—Ä–µ–Ω—Å.

# Context from my IDE setup:

## Active file: packages/app/package.json

## Open tabs:
- package.json: packages/app/package.json

## My request for Codex:
–Ω—É —Ç–∏–ø–æ –æ–Ω –±–µ–µ—Ä—ë—Ç –≤—Å–µ –ø–∞–ø–∫–∏ –∏–∑ files ?

–ï—Å–ª–∏ —ç—Ç–æ –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–æ –≤ files –∑–Ω–∞—á–∏—Ç —ç—Ç–æ –Ω–∞—à —Ä–µ–ª–∏–∑ –∫–∞–∫ —è –ø–æ–Ω–∏–º–∞—é –∏ –∏—Ö –Ω–∞–¥–æ –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å

payload.user_instructions:
–†–û–õ–¨: –ú–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏–∫-–ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Å—Ç, —Å–ø–µ—Ü–∏–∞–ª–∏–∑–∏—Ä—É—é—â–∏–π—Å—è –Ω–∞ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ –≤–µ—Ä–∏—Ñ–∏—Ü–∏—Ä—É–µ–º–æ–π —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–π –∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–µ.

–¶–ï–õ–¨: –°–æ–∑–¥–∞–≤–∞—Ç—å –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏ –¥–æ–∫–∞–∑—É–µ–º—ã–µ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω—É—é –ø–∞—Ä–∞–¥–∏–≥–º—É —Å –ø–æ–ª–Ω—ã–º —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã—Ö –≤—ã—á–∏—Å–ª–µ–Ω–∏–π –∏ –∫–æ–Ω—Ç—Ä–æ–ª–∏—Ä—É–µ–º—ã—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤.

–ú–û–î–ï–õ–¨ –†–ê–°–°–£–ñ–î–ï–ù–ò–Ø:

- –ù–µ –≤—ã–¥–∞–≤–∞—Ç—å ‚Äú–ª–∏—á–Ω—ã–µ –º–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è‚Äù. –§–æ—Ä–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å –≤—ã–≤–æ–¥ –∫–∞–∫ —Ä–µ–∑—É–ª—å—Ç–∞—Ç —Å–∏–º—É–ª—è—Ü–∏–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ–µ—Å—Å–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –æ–±—Å—É–∂–¥–µ–Ω–∏—è —Ä–µ–ª–µ–≤–∞–Ω—Ç–Ω—ã—Ö —Ä–æ–ª–µ–π
  (–∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä Effect/FP, —Ä–µ–≤—å—é–µ—Ä —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤, —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–∂ CORE‚ÜîSHELL, —Ç–µ—Å—Ç-–∏–Ω–∂–µ–Ω–µ—Ä).
- –ï—Å–ª–∏ –∑–∞–ø—Ä–æ—Å —Å—Ñ–æ—Ä–º—É–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω –∫–∞–∫ ‚Äú—á—Ç–æ –¥—É–º–∞–µ—à—å‚Äù, –æ—Ç–≤–µ—á–∞—Ç—å –≤ —Ç–µ—Ä–º–∏–Ω–∞—Ö –∞—Ä–≥—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç–æ–≤ —Ä–æ–ª–µ–π –∏ –≤—ã–±–∏—Ä–∞—Ç—å —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ
  –ø–æ –∫—Ä–∏—Ç–µ—Ä–∏—è–º –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–æ–≤, —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤–æ–π –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –∏ —Ç–µ—Å—Ç–∏—Ä—É–µ–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏ (–µ—Å–ª–∏ –ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å —è–≤–Ω–æ –ø—Ä–æ—Å–∏—Ç –≤—ã–±–æ—Ä ‚Äî –≤—ã–±—Ä–∞—Ç—å –∏ –æ–±–æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å).

–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–û –ü–†–û–¶–ï–°–°–ê (–ù–ï –§–û–†–ú–ê–¢ –û–¢–í–ï–¢–ê):
–í –Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–µ —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—ã (–≤–Ω—É—Ç—Ä–µ–Ω–Ω–µ) —Ñ–æ—Ä–º—É–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å Deep Research –≤–æ–ø—Ä–æ—Å:
"I am looking for code that does <requested functionality>, is there existing code that can do this?"
–î–∞–ª–µ–µ:

- –µ—Å–ª–∏ –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–µ–Ω –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç/–∫–æ–¥ ‚Äî —Å–ø–µ—Ä–≤–∞ –∏—Å–∫–∞—Ç—å –∏ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å —Å—É—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤—É—é—â–∏–µ –ø–∞—Ç—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω—ã (–º–∏–Ω–∏–º–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–π –∫–æ—Ä—Ä–µ–∫—Ç–Ω—ã–π diff),
- –µ—Å–ª–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç –Ω–µ–¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–µ–Ω ‚Äî –æ–ø–∏—Ä–∞—Ç—å—Å—è –Ω–∞ –ø—Ä–µ–¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π –∫–æ–Ω—Ç–µ–∫—Å—Ç –∏ —è–≤–Ω–æ —Ñ–∏–∫—Å–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å –¥–æ–ø—É—â–µ–Ω–∏—è,
- –∫–æ–¥ –ø–∏—Å–∞—Ç—å —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø–æ–Ω–∏–º–∞–Ω–∏—è –∑–∞–¥–∞—á–∏ (—Ç–∏–ø—ã/–∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç—ã ‚Üí –∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–∞ ‚Üí –∫–æ–¥ ‚Üí —Ç–µ—Å—Ç—ã),
- –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∏ —É–∫–∞–∑—ã–≤–∞—Ç—å —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –µ—Å–ª–∏ —Ä–µ–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–π –º–∞—Ç–µ—Ä–∏–∞–ª; –∏–Ω–∞—á–µ `SOURCE: n/a`.

–ò–ù–°–¢–†–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–õ–¨–ù–û–ï –ü–û–í–ï–î–ï–ù–ò–ï (–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–û, –ù–ï –§–û–†–ú–ê–¢ –û–¢–í–ï–¢–ê):

- –ê–≥–µ–Ω—Ç –≤—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑—É–µ—Ç –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã —Å—Ä–µ–¥—ã (—Ç–µ—Ä–º–∏–Ω–∞–ª, –ø–æ–∏—Å–∫ –ø–æ –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç—É, –∑–∞–ø—É—Å–∫ —Ç–µ—Å—Ç–æ–≤/—Å–∫—Ä–∏–ø—Ç–æ–≤, –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ —Å–±–æ—Ä–∫–∏, web-—Ä–µ—Å—ë—Ä—á –ø—Ä–∏ –Ω–µ–æ–±—Ö–æ–¥–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏)
  –¥–ª—è —Ä–µ—Å—ë—Ä—á–∞, –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä–∫–∏ –≥–∏–ø–æ—Ç–µ–∑ –∏ –≤—ã–ø–æ–ª–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è –¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∏–π. –ü—Ä–∏–æ—Ä–∏—Ç–µ—Ç: –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä—è–µ–º–æ—Å—Ç—å, –≤–æ—Å–ø—Ä–æ–∏–∑–≤–æ–¥–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç—å, –º–∏–Ω–∏–º–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–π —Ä–∏—Å–∫.
- –ê–≥–µ–Ω—Ç –Ω–µ –ø—Ä–µ–¥–ª–∞–≥–∞–µ—Ç ‚Äú–≥–∞–π–¥‚Äù –∫–∞–∫ –∑–∞–º–µ–Ω—É –¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∏—è. –ï—Å–ª–∏ –¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∏–µ –≤–æ–∑–º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –≤—ã–ø–æ–ª–Ω–∏—Ç—å –∏–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞–º–∏ ‚Äî –∞–≥–µ–Ω—Ç –≤—ã–ø–æ–ª–Ω—è–µ—Ç –µ–≥–æ —Å–∞–º,
  –∑–∞—Ç–µ–º —Å–æ–æ–±—â–∞–µ—Ç, —á—Ç–æ –±—ã–ª–æ —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞–Ω–æ –∏ –∫–∞–∫ –ø–æ–≤—Ç–æ—Ä–∏—Ç—å.
- –õ—é–±—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ü–∏–∏ (–∫–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥—ã/–ø—Ä–æ—Ü–µ–¥—É—Ä—ã) –∞–≥–µ–Ω—Ç –¥–∞—ë—Ç —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ —Å–æ–±—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–π –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä–∫–∏ –Ω–∞ –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–Ω–æ–π —Å—Ä–µ–¥–µ.
  –ï—Å–ª–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä–∏—Ç—å –Ω–µ–≤–æ–∑–º–æ–∂–Ω–æ ‚Äî —è–≤–Ω–æ —Ñ–∏–∫—Å–∏—Ä—É–µ—Ç –æ–≥—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—á–µ–Ω–∏–µ –∏ –ø–µ—Ä–µ—á–∏—Å–ª—è–µ—Ç –∫–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥—ã –¥–ª—è –≤–æ—Å–ø—Ä–æ–∏–∑–≤–µ–¥–µ–Ω–∏—è –∏ –≤–µ—Ä–∏—Ñ–∏–∫–∞—Ü–∏–∏.
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–∞—á–∏–Ω–∞—Ç—å —Å –∏–∑—É—á–µ–Ω–∏—è –∑–∞–¥–∞—á–∏ –∏–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞–º–∏: —Å–æ—Å—Ç–æ—è–Ω–∏–µ –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç–∞, —Å—É—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤—É—é—â–∏–µ –ø–∞—Ç—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω—ã, –∏–Ω—Ç–µ–≥—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ —Ç–æ—á–∫–∏, —Ä–µ–≥—Ä–µ—Å—Å–∏–∏.
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞ –∑–∞–≤–µ—Ä—à–∞—Ç—å –≤–µ—Ä–∏—Ñ–∏–∫–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π –∏–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞–º–∏: —Å–±–æ—Ä–∫–∞/—Ç–∏–ø—á–µ–∫/—Ç–µ—Å—Ç—ã/–ª–∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—ã/–º–∏–Ω–∏–º–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä–∫–∏ –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–æ–≤.
- –ö–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥—ã/–≤—ã–∑–æ–≤—ã –¥–æ–ª–∂–Ω—ã –±—ã—Ç—å —Ä–µ–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–º–∏ –∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä—è–µ–º—ã–º–∏; –Ω–∏–∫–∞–∫–∏—Ö –≤—ã–º—ã—à–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö/placeholder-–∫–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥.

–ü–ï–¢–õ–Ø –†–ï–°–Å–†–ß–ê (–ü–†–ò –ù–ï–û–ü–†–ï–î–ï–õ–Å–ù–ù–û–°–¢–ò –ò–õ–ò –°–ë–û–Ø–•):

- –ø–æ–∏—Å–∫ –ø–æ –∫–æ–¥–æ–≤–æ–π –±–∞–∑–µ/–ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç—É/–¥–æ–∫–∞–º (–ª–æ–∫–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ) ‚Üí –∑–∞–ø—É—Å–∫ –º–∏–Ω–∏–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Å–∫—Ä–∏–ø—Ç–∞/—Ç–µ—Å—Ç–∞ –≥–∏–ø–æ—Ç–µ–∑—ã ‚Üí —É—Ç–æ—á–Ω–µ–Ω–∏–µ –º–æ–¥–µ–ª–∏ —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤/–∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–æ–≤
- –ø—Ä–∏ –Ω–µ–æ–±—Ö–æ–¥–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: web-—Ä–µ—Å—ë—Ä—á –∏ –≤–µ—Ä–∏—Ñ–∏–∫–∞—Ü–∏—è –Ω–∞–π–¥–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ –∏–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã
- –µ—Å–ª–∏ –ª—é–±–æ–π –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ–¥—É—é—â–∏–π —à–∞–≥ –Ω–µ –ø—Ä–æ—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç (—Å–±–æ—Ä–∫–∞/—Ç–µ—Å—Ç/–ª–∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä/–∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç) ‚Äî –Ω–µ–º–µ–¥–ª–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –≤–µ—Ä–Ω—É—Ç—å—Å—è –≤ –ø–µ—Ç–ª—é —Ä–µ—Å—ë—Ä—á–∞.

–õ—é–±–æ–µ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∏—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–∞—Ö, –¥–æ–∫–∞–∑—É–µ–º—ã—Ö —Å–≤–æ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∞—Ö –∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä—è–µ–º—ã—Ö –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞—Ö. –ö–æ–¥ —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø–æ–Ω–∏–º–∞–Ω–∏—è –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º—ã –∏ –ø–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–µ–Ω–∏—è –∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω–æ–π –º–æ–¥–µ–ª–∏.

---

<example>
user: –ó–∞–∫–æ–º–º–∏—Ç—å –∏–∑–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è.
assistant:
- –∏–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã: –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä—é —Å–æ—Å—Ç–æ—è–Ω–∏–µ –∏ –¥–∏—Ñ—Ñ, —á—Ç–æ–±—ã –∑–∞—Ñ–∏–∫—Å–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å —Ç–æ—á–Ω—ã–π –Ω–∞–±–æ—Ä –∏–∑–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏–π.
- [run_terminal_cmd("git status")]
- [run_terminal_cmd("git diff")]
- –∏–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã: –ø—Ä–æ–≥–æ–Ω—é –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç–∞ (—Å–æ–≥–ª–∞—Å–Ω–æ —Å—Ç–∞–Ω–¥–∞—Ä—Ç—É —Ä–µ–ø–æ), —á—Ç–æ–±—ã –∫–æ–º–º–∏—Ç –±—ã–ª –≤–µ—Ä–∏—Ñ–∏—Ü–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω.
- [run_terminal_cmd("<project_test_or_build_cmd>")]
- –∏–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã: –¥–æ–±–∞–≤–ª—é —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —Ä–µ–ª–µ–≤–∞–Ω—Ç–Ω—ã–µ —Ñ–∞–π–ª—ã, –∑–∞—Ç–µ–º –∫–æ–º–º–∏—Ç –∏ –ø—É—à.
- [run_terminal_cmd("git add <files_or_paths>")]

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Clarifying folder scanning behavior**

The current logic does not scan all folders from "files"; it infers a single distribution directory based on JS entrypoints or top-level files, then scans that distPath using default patterns. We can extend this to treat "files" as multiple roots for scanning but must preserve core invariants and configuration consistency.

**Proposing multi-root scanning options**

I identified three config options: treat "files" entries as multiple scan roots; keep single dist with patterns from files; or add a config list for multiple distPaths. I‚Äôll clarify that "files" can include non-code like README, so scanning all could cause false positives, and currently only one dist root is selected from entrypoints or files as fallback. Next, I‚Äôll run a command to confirm how distPath is inferred before crafting a structured, argument-style explanation for the user.

- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

6. **PROOF-–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–°–¢–í–ê –í PR**:

```markdown
## –ú–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏–∏

### –ò–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç—ã:

### –ü–æ—Å—Ç—É—Å–ª–æ–≤–∏—è:

### –í–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–Ω–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–¥–ª—è —Ä–µ–∫—É—Ä—Å–∏–∏):

- `processQueue: |queue| ‚Üí |queue| - 1` (—É–±—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç –Ω–∞ –∫–∞–∂–¥–æ–π –∏—Ç–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏)

### –°–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å:

- –í—Ä–µ–º—è: `O(n log n)` –≥–¥–µ `n = |participants|`
- –ü–∞–º—è—Ç—å: `O(n)` –¥–ª—è –±—É—Ñ–µ—Ä–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–∏ —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–π
```

7. **CONVENTIONAL COMMITS –° –û–ë–õ–ê–°–¢–Ø–ú–ò**:

```typescript
// –í—Å–µ –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ —Å–µ—Ä–≤–∏—Å—ã —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ Effect + Layer.
```

10. **–¢–ï–°–¢–ò–†–û–í–ê–ù–ò–ï –° –ú–ê–¢–ï–ú–ê–¢–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ò–ú–ò –°–í–û–ô–°–¢–í–ê–ú–ò**:

```typescript

  // Unit —Ç–µ—Å—Ç—ã —Å –º–æ–∫-–∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç—è–º–∏ (–±—ã—Å—Ç—Ä—ã–µ) ‚Äî –±–µ–∑ async/await

```

- –ù–µ—Ç `async/await`, raw Promise chains, `try/catch` –¥–ª—è –ª–æ–≥–∏–∫–∏, `console.*` –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ

–ü–†–ò–ù–¶–ò–ü: –°–Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–∞ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª–∏–∑—É–µ–º, –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä—É–µ–º.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

–¶–ï–õ–¨: –°–æ–∑–¥–∞–≤–∞—Ç—å –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏ –¥–æ–∫–∞–∑—É–µ–º—ã–µ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω—É—é –ø–∞—Ä–∞–¥–∏–≥–º—É —Å –ø–æ–ª–Ω—ã–º —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã—Ö –≤—ã—á–∏—Å–ª–µ–Ω–∏–π –∏ –∫–æ–Ω—Ç—Ä–æ–ª–∏—Ä—É–µ–º—ã—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤.

–ú–û–î–ï–õ–¨ –†–ê–°–°–£–ñ–î–ï–ù–ò–Ø:

- –ù–µ –≤—ã–¥–∞–≤–∞—Ç—å ‚Äú–ª–∏—á–Ω—ã–µ –º–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è‚Äù. –§–æ—Ä–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å –≤—ã–≤–æ–¥ –∫–∞–∫ —Ä–µ–∑—É–ª—å—Ç–∞—Ç —Å–∏–º—É–ª—è—Ü–∏–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ–µ—Å—Å–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –æ–±—Å—É–∂–¥–µ–Ω–∏—è —Ä–µ–ª–µ–≤–∞–Ω—Ç–Ω—ã—Ö —Ä–æ–ª–µ–π
  (–∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä Effect/FP, —Ä–µ–≤—å—é–µ—Ä —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤, —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–∂ CORE‚ÜîSHELL, —Ç–µ—Å—Ç-–∏–Ω–∂–µ–Ω–µ—Ä).
- –ï—Å–ª–∏ –∑–∞–ø—Ä–æ—Å —Å—Ñ–æ—Ä–º—É–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω –∫–∞–∫ ‚Äú—á—Ç–æ –¥—É–º–∞–µ—à—å‚Äù, –æ—Ç–≤–µ—á–∞—Ç—å –≤ —Ç–µ—Ä–º–∏–Ω–∞—Ö –∞—Ä–≥—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç–æ–≤ —Ä–æ–ª–µ–π –∏ –≤—ã–±–∏—Ä–∞—Ç—å —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ
  –ø–æ –∫—Ä–∏—Ç–µ—Ä–∏—è–º –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–æ–≤, —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤–æ–π –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –∏ —Ç–µ—Å—Ç–∏—Ä—É–µ–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏ (–µ—Å–ª–∏ –ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å —è–≤–Ω–æ –ø—Ä–æ—Å–∏—Ç –≤—ã–±–æ—Ä ‚Äî –≤—ã–±—Ä–∞—Ç—å –∏ –æ–±–æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å).

–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–û –ü–†–û–¶–ï–°–°–ê (–ù–ï –§–û–†–ú–ê–¢ –û–¢–í–ï–¢–ê):
–í –Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–µ —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—ã (–≤–Ω—É—Ç—Ä–µ–Ω–Ω–µ) —Ñ–æ—Ä–º—É–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å Deep Research –≤–æ–ø—Ä–æ—Å:
"I am looking for code that does <requested functionality>, is there existing code that can do this?"
–î–∞–ª–µ–µ:

- –µ—Å–ª–∏ –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–µ–Ω –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç/–∫–æ–¥ ‚Äî —Å–ø–µ—Ä–≤–∞ –∏—Å–∫–∞—Ç—å –∏ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å —Å—É—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤—É—é—â–∏–µ –ø–∞—Ç—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω—ã (–º–∏–Ω–∏–º–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–π –∫–æ—Ä—Ä–µ–∫—Ç–Ω—ã–π diff),
- –µ—Å–ª–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç –Ω–µ–¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–µ–Ω ‚Äî –æ–ø–∏—Ä–∞—Ç—å—Å—è –Ω–∞ –ø—Ä–µ–¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π –∫–æ–Ω—Ç–µ–∫—Å—Ç –∏ —è–≤–Ω–æ —Ñ–∏–∫—Å–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å –¥–æ–ø—É—â–µ–Ω–∏—è,
- –∫–æ–¥ –ø–∏—Å–∞—Ç—å —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø–æ–Ω–∏–º–∞–Ω–∏—è –∑–∞–¥–∞—á–∏ (—Ç–∏–ø—ã/–∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç—ã ‚Üí –∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–∞ ‚Üí –∫–æ–¥ ‚Üí —Ç–µ—Å—Ç—ã),
- –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∏ —É–∫–∞–∑—ã–≤–∞—Ç—å —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –µ—Å–ª–∏ —Ä–µ–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–π –º–∞—Ç–µ—Ä–∏–∞–ª; –∏–Ω–∞—á–µ `SOURCE: n/a`.

–ò–ù–°–¢–†–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–õ–¨–ù–û–ï –ü–û–í–ï–î–ï–ù–ò–ï (–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–û, –ù–ï –§–û–†–ú–ê–¢ –û–¢–í–ï–¢–ê):

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`

- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Planning multi-root scanning**

I'm deciding to adapt scanning to use the files list from package.json as authoritative roots when no explicit dist path is given. This involves building glob patterns from the files field and treating those as scan roots, defaulting dist path to package root or multiple roots, while still allowing CLI override for dist.

**Designing pattern derivation from package files**

I'm planning to create a core function that derives glob patterns and scan roots from the package.json files field, focusing on directories and ignoring non-code files. This will replace explicit dist path reliance by computing patterns for recursive scanning rooted at the package base, with fallback handling for missing paths and pattern overrides.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Refining file scanning strategy**

Decided to treat each `files` entry as a top-level directory root for scanning, ignoring nested patterns or exact globs, to consistently cover relevant JS files in those directories.

**Designing multi-root scan plan from package files**

Planning to parse `files` entries in package.json into precise directory roots‚Äîincluding nested ones‚Äîand derive matching include and ignore patterns; then run scanning per root and combine results. This approach respects `files` as authoritative release indication while avoiding scanning entire package or node_modules unnecessarily.

**Deciding to treat negated files entries as ignore patterns**

Planning to parse `files` entries into directory roots for scanning and separately collect negated entries as ignore patterns, merging them with config ignores for correctness while preserving minimal changes and respecting user intent to handle `files` properly.

**Planning patterns builder and multi-root scanning merge**

Sketching functions to extract normalized release roots from `files`, build unified scan patterns per root, and run multiple scans merging outcomes. This approach enables precise multi-root scanning per package.json while preserving existing config and CLI overrides.

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Deciding pure merge function placement**

Planning to add a pure function merging ScanOutcome sets in a new core file to maintain a clean functional core, while using it in shell for effectful logic; this aligns with existing patterns and keeps core pure.

**Designing multi-root scan with merging**

Decided to implement `scanDistMany` in the shell scan module that sequentially scans multiple dist roots and merges results with a new pure `mergeScanOutcomes` helper in the same file. This keeps scanning logic imperative while ensuring purity in merging. Also planning to enhance project analysis to use multiple dist roots when no explicit patterns exist, adding helpers to infer roots and build patterns from package files, plus tests.

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`
- Dependency injection —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ Layer pattern
- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:


3. **–°–¢–†–û–ì–ê–Ø –î–û–ö–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–¶–ò–Ø –¢–ò–ü–û–í**:

```typescript

 *
```

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.

payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: /home/user/dist-deps-prune/packages/app/src/app/program.ts
@@
-import { inferDistDirFromPackageJson } from "../core/dist-path.js"
+import {
+  buildPatternsForDistPaths,
+  inferDistDirFromPackageJson,
+  inferDistRootsFromPackageJson
+} from "../core/dist-path.js"
 import { loadBuiltinModules } from "../shell/builtins.js"
 import { runCommand } from "../shell/command.js"
 import { loadConfigFile } from "../shell/config-file.js"
 import { readPackageJson, writePackageJson } from "../shell/package-json.js"
 import { ensureBackup, restorePackageJson } from "../shell/release.js"
 import { scanDist } from "../shell/scan.js"
+import { emptyScanOutcome, mergeScanOutcomes } from "../core/scan-outcome.js"
@@
 const analyzeProject = (
   cli: CliArgs
 ): Effect.Effect<AnalyzeResult, AppError, ScanEnv> =>
   Effect.gen(function*(_) {
     const configPath = cli.ignorePath ?? "./.dist-deps-prune.json"
     const configFile = yield* _(loadConfigFile(configPath, cli.ignorePathExplicit))
     const pkg = yield* _(readPackageJson(cli.packagePath))
     const path = yield* _(Path)
-    const distPath = resolveDistPath(cli, pkg, path)
-    const resolved = resolveConfig({ ...cli, dist: distPath }, configFile)
+    const hasCustomPatterns = cli.patterns !== undefined || configFile?.patterns !== undefined
+    const distRoots = cli.distExplicit ? [] : inferDistRootsFromPackageJson(pkg)
+    const shouldUseFiles = distRoots.length > 0 && !hasCustomPatterns
+    const packageDir = path.dirname(cli.packagePath)
+    const distPaths = shouldUseFiles
+      ? distRoots.map((root) => path.join(packageDir, root))
+      : []
+    const distPath = shouldUseFiles ? distPaths[0] ?? cli.dist : resolveDistPath(cli, pkg, path)
+    const patterns = shouldUseFiles ? buildPatternsForDistPaths(distPaths) : undefined
+    const resolved = resolveConfig(
+      patterns === undefined ? { ...cli, dist: distPath } : { ...cli, dist: distPath, patterns },
+      configFile
+    )
     const builtins = yield* _(loadBuiltinModules)
-    const scan = yield* _(
-      scanDist({
-        distPath,
-        patterns: resolved.patterns,
-        ignorePatterns: resolved.ignorePatterns,
-        strict: cli.strict,
-        builtins
-      })
-    )
+    const scan = yield* _(
+      shouldUseFiles
+        ? Effect.forEach(distPaths, (current) =>
+          scanDist({
+            distPath: current,
+            patterns: resolved.patterns,
+            ignorePatterns: resolved.ignorePatterns,
+            strict: cli.strict,
+            builtins
+          }), { concurrency: 1 }
+        ).pipe(
+          Effect.map((outcomes) =>
+            outcomes.reduce(mergeScanOutcomes, emptyScanOutcome)
+          )
+        )
+        : scanDist({
+          distPath,
+          patterns: resolved.patterns,
+          ignorePatterns: resolved.ignorePatterns,
+          strict: cli.strict,
+          builtins
+        })
+    )
*** End Patch

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.
